pros: Free coffee, free fruit, some nice ground level employees.
cons:
If you're here hopefully you've read the negative reviews and carefully considered the authenticity of the five star, glowing reviews.

No benefits package- fair enough, it's a charity, but there is absolutely no time in lieu considered for the unpaid overtime expected.

The working practice is abysmal, with poor communication, no roadmapping, silo departments and general disorganisation. Nepotism has created a management structure of the friends and family of management who are often too unqualifed and inexperienced to come up with workable ideas and campaigns- and you will bear the brunt of this: you will be given an impossible workload and impossible deadlines to meet. You will be expected to do unpaid and thankless overtime. You will be micromanaged and have to deal with a disorganised sign off procedures that makes consistent quality of work unattainable. You will be expected to manage shortfalls in time, resources and staff that should have been addressed long ago  by management.

And worst of all you will be publically bullied and berated for failures beyond your control. Mismanagement creates models doomed to fail and you will be aggressively held accountable.

Bullying from the top down is rife: even the sycophants who feed the insaitable egos of those in charge have been aggressively criticized, belittled and reduced to tears. Obviously there is a huge turnover. Most people have left under bad terms. Avoid the stress and look for something else. You can do better.

review_title: The growth of any organisation takes courage and patience
pros: Penny Appeal is a growing charity, a vibrant place to work in if you're heart and mind are in the right place. Hard work, sincerity and willingness to evolve are a quality that drives the leadership in this organisation. This is a place for people who want to make a difference in the world because it is a place that has behind it some of the very best in the industry.
cons: Not always the best with organisation which can mean the pressure is higher than usual and arguably sometimes recruits people that shouldn't have been a part of the organisation from the very beginning. The ethos in this organisation and the charity world requires that you engage your heart and mind into this and if you're a 9 to 5 type of person who doesn't want to go above and beyond and simply wants to enjoy a pay packet at the end, then this organisation isn't for you and this industry isn't for you either.
